information: È universalmente riconosciuto che un lettore che osserva il layout di una pagina viene distratto dal contenuto testuale se questo è leggibile. Lo scopo dell’utilizzo del Lorem Ipsum è che offre una normale distribuzione delle lettere (al contrario di quanto avviene se si utilizzano brevi frasi ripetute, ad esempio “testo qui”), apparendo come un normale blocco di testo leggibile. Molti software di impaginazione e di web design utilizzano Lorem Ipsum come testo modello. Molte versioni del testo sono state prodotte negli anni, a volte casualmente, a volte di proposito (ad esempio inserendo passaggi ironici).
name: Albatross Runner

information: Al contrario di quanto si pensi, Lorem Ipsum non è semplicemente una sequenza casuale di caratteri. Risale ad un classico della letteratura latina del 45 AC, cosa che lo rende vecchio di 2000 anni. Richard McClintock, professore di latino al Hampden-Sydney College in Virginia, ha ricercato una delle più oscure parole latine, consectetur, da un passaggio del Lorem Ipsum e ha scoperto tra i vari testi in cui è citata, la fonte da cui è tratto il testo, le sezioni 1.10.32 and 1.10.33 del de Finibus Bonorum et Malorumdi Cicerone. Questo testo è un trattato su teorie di etica, molto popolare nel Rinascimento. La prima riga del Lorem Ipsum, Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.., è tratta da un passaggio della sezione 1.10.32.
name: Angler Runner

information: è un testo segnaposto utilizzato nel settore della tipografia e della stampa. Lorem Ipsum è considerato il testo segnaposto standard sin dal sedicesimo secolo, quando un anonimo tipografo prese una cassetta di caratteri e li assemblò per preparare un testo campione. È sopravvissuto non solo a più di cinque secoli, ma anche al passaggio alla videoimpaginazione, pervenendoci sostanzialmente inalterato. Fu reso popolare, negli anni ’60, con la diffusione dei fogli di caratteri trasferibili “Letraset”, che contenevano passaggi del Lorem Ipsum, e più recentemente da software di impaginazione come Aldus PageMaker, che includeva versioni del Lorem Ipsum.
name: Anteater Runner

information: è un testo segnaposto utilizzato nel settore della tipografia e della stampa. Lorem Ipsum è considerato il testo segnaposto standard sin dal sedicesimo secolo, quando un anonimo tipografo prese una cassetta di caratteri e li assemblò per preparare un testo campione. È sopravvissuto non solo a più di cinque secoli, ma anche al passaggio alla videoimpaginazione, pervenendoci sostanzialmente inalterato. Fu reso popolare, negli anni ’60, con la diffusione dei fogli di caratteri trasferibili “Letraset”, che contenevano passaggi del Lorem Ipsum, e più recentemente da software di impaginazione come Aldus PageMaker, che includeva versioni del Lorem Ipsum.
name: Baboon Runner

information: è un testo segnaposto utilizzato nel settore della tipografia e della stampa. Lorem Ipsum è considerato il testo segnaposto standard sin dal sedicesimo secolo, quando un anonimo tipografo prese una cassetta di caratteri e li assemblò per preparare un testo campione. È sopravvissuto non solo a più di cinque secoli, ma anche al passaggio alla videoimpaginazione, pervenendoci sostanzialmente inalterato. Fu reso popolare, negli anni ’60, con la diffusione dei fogli di caratteri trasferibili “Letraset”, che contenevano passaggi del Lorem Ipsum, e più recentemente da software di impaginazione come Aldus PageMaker, che includeva versioni del Lorem Ipsum.
name: Bear Runner

information: Phobos is the larger and closer of Mars' two moons. It orbits so close to the planet that it moves around Mars faster than Mars rotates. So if you live on Mars, it looks like Phobos rises in the west and then sets in the east just over 4 hours later. And this happens twice a day!
name: Beaver Runner

information: Deimos is the outer moon of Mars. Its two largest craters are Swift and Voltaire, named after the 18th century authors of "Gulliver's Travels" and "Candide." In his travels, Gulliver met fictional Laputans who had "discovered" that Mars had two moons. The book was written fifty years BEFORE real-life humans actually discovered them!
name: Bee Runner

information: The asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter is spread over so much space that it's actually mostly empty-- no need to dodge rocks like in the movies. When first discovered in the early 1800's, asteroids were hard to distinguish from stars. Thus the name aster-oid, meaning "star-like." We now know they aren't stars at all, but the name's stuck.
name: Beetle Runner

information: Ceres is the largest asteroid in the belt between Mars and Jupiter. It's classified as a "dwarf planet," like Pluto. It very likely has an ocean of liquid water under its surface, which may harbor life. NASA's "Dawn" probe is expected to arrive there in February 2015, so we'll know more then.
name: Bison Runner

information: The largest planet in the Solar System, named after the ancient Roman king of gods. A giant storm over 12,000 km (~7,500 mi) wide that's been going on since at least the 17th century forms the Great Red Spot on its surface.
name: Boar Runner

information: The four "Galilean" moons of Jupiter were discovered by Galileo in 1610. Io is the innermost of the four. With over 400 active volcanoes, it's the most geologically active object in the Solar System.
name: Bug Runner

information: The second Galilean moon of Jupiter, Europa, is one of the front-runners for possible extraterrestrial life in the Solar System. There's no proof yet, but there could be life in its under-ice ocean. The 2013 film "Europa Report" provided a fictional possibility of that discovery, and the European Space Agency's "JUICE" probe will provide a first close look when it gets there in 2030.
name: Bulldog Runner

information: The third "Galilean" moon of Jupiter, Ganymede, is the largest moon in the solar system and has a larger diameter than the planet Mercury. A saltwater ocean is believed to exist nearly 200km below its surface, sandwiched between layers of ice.
name: Bullfinch Runner

information: Callisto is farthest of the four Galilean moons of Jupiter, all discovered in 1610 by Galileo. A 2003 NASA report proposed a surface base on Callisto. With its low levels of radiation and geological stability, it could be a sort of refueling waystation for vessels headed toward other moons of Jupiter or farther into the outer Solar System.
name: Butterfly-1 Runner

information: Saturn is perennial favorite because of its famous rings. The rings are made of countless small, orbiting particles of water, ice, and trace rocky material. Confused by the way they seemed to disappear when oriented directly at Earth, Galileo once wondered "has Saturn swallowed his children?" This referenced the ancient Roman god Saturn's bad habit of eating his children to prevent them from overthrowing him.
name: Butterfly Runner

information: Mimas is the closest of Saturn's major moons. It's the smallest known astronomical body that is round due to self-gravitation. Mimas has been noted for its resemblance to the Death Star in the film "Star Wars." But anyone flying close will note: "that's no space station... it's a moon!"
name: Capybara Runner

information: Enceladus, a moon of Saturn, has ice volcanoes at its South Pole. ICE VOLCANOES! Some of what shoots out of them comes back down as snow, some gets caught up and adds to Saturn's rings, and some reaches Saturn. Ice. Volcanoes.
name: Centipede Runner

information: Tethys is a moon of Saturn, covered mostly by water ice that makes its surface very reflective. But a small fraction of the surface is covered by an unidentified dark material...
name: Chameleon Runner

information: Dione, a moon of Saturn, is composed mostly of water ice and is known for its "ice cliffs." These were a bit of a mystery until 2004, when the Cassini probe took close-up pictures and revealed them as the result of massive tectonic fractures.
name: Cock Runner

information: In 2008, NASA announced the possibility that Rhea, a moon of Saturn, might have its own rings. But in 2010, the Cassini probe found no evidence and it now seems unlikely. Still, the discovery of some mysterious blue ice along Rhea's equator keeps the possibility open.
name: Colibri Runner

information: By far the largest moon of Saturn, Titan is the only place in the Solar System other than Earth with stable bodies of surface liquid (it has methane rivers and lakes) as well as the only other place with a nitrogen-rich atmosphere (it has a climate complete with wind and methane rain).
name: Cow Runner

information: Iapetus is the farthest major moon of Saturn and has two unique features. First, it has two huge sections of different colors: one dark brown and one bright gray. The two colors interlock like the surface of a tennis ball. Second, it has a long ridge along its equator that makes the moon look a little like a walnut shell. So to recap: Iapetus is the walnut tennis ball moon.
name: Crab Runner

information: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun. OK. Let's have a talk about its name. Astronomers usually stress the first syllable (EWR-i-nis), but stressing the second (ew-RAY-nes) is OK too. You should also ask the nearest 8-year-old which one they prefer.
name: Uranus

information: Miranda, smallest and innermost of Uranus's five major moons, was named after the character from Shakespeare's "The Tempest." It has very rough, broken terrain on its icy surface. Which may be because of... ice volcanoes!
name: Miranda

information: Ariel is the second-closest of Uranus's major moons. Because it is on its side as it rotates the Sun, it is subject to an extreme seasonal cycle. This also means Ariel's poles see permanent daylight or night lasting for half a Uranian year (42 Earth years). Winter is coming, indeed.
name: Ariel

information: Umbriel is the darkest of the Uranian moons, and imaging of its surface is still of fairly low resolution. The closest look we've had was with the Voyager 2, which got within a mere 325,000 km.
name: Umbriel

information: Titania is the largest Uranian moon. It might have a liquid ocean buried deep inside, sandwiched between its core and mantle layers.
name: Titania

information: The surface of Oberon, slightly dark and red in color, appears to have been primarily shaped by asteroid and comet impacts. It's three biggest craters are named Hamlet, Othello, and Macbeth.
name: Oberon

information: Neptune is the eighth and furthest planet from the Sun. Its atmosphere has pretty nasty weather; wind speeds can reach 2,100 km/hr (1,300 mph)!
name: Neptune

information: Triton, largest moon of Neptune, is the only large moon in the Solar System that rotates in the opposite direction to its planet's rotation. It was the setting for the Nebula-nominated 1976 novel of the same name.
name: Triton

information: Extending far past Neptune is the Kuiper Belt. It's similar to the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, except 20 times as wide and 20-200 times more massive. It was only discovered in 1992!
name: The Kuiper Belt

information: Discovered in 1930, Pluto was originally considered the ninth planet. But in 2006 it was reclassified as a dwarf planet because it's not big enough to clear the neighborhood around its orbit.
name: Pluto

information: With all these planets and moons on their orbit, it can be hard to remember that the Solar System itself is orbiting the center of the Milky Way galaxy at 220 km/sec (140 mi/s). And that our galaxy, in turn, has its own path among other galaxies. There's plenty out there to discover.
name: Interstellar Space
